revision.text:
{{Advanced Placement}} '''AP Physics C: Mechanics''' (often referred to as '''AP C Mechanics''', '''AP Mechanics''', or simply '''AP Physics C''') is an [[Advanced Placement]] [[science]] course that studies [[Newtonian mechanics]]. It is one of the [[AP Physics]] courses offered in some [[Secondary education in the United States|U.S. secondary schools]].
==Course content== Intended to be equivalent to an introductory [[college]] course in mechanics for physics or engineering majors,<ref name=PhysCMechoverview>{{citation | url = http://media.collegeboard.com/digitalServices/pdf/ap/ap-course-overviews/ap-physics-c-mechanics-course-overview.pdf | format = PDF | title = AP® PHYSICS C: MECHANICS | publisher = [[College Board]] | date = December 2016 | access-date = January 30, 2017}}</ref> the course modules are:<ref name=PhysCMechoverview/> * Kinematics * Newton’s laws of motion * Work, energy and power * Systems of particles and linear momentum * Circular motion and rotation * Oscillations and gravitation.
Methods of [[calculus]] are used wherever appropriate in formulating physical principles and in applying them to physical problems. Therefore, students should have completed or be concurrently enrolled in a calculus class.<ref name=PhysCMechoverview/>
This course may be combined with [[AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism]] to make a unified Physics C course that prepares for both exams.
==AP test==
The course culminates in an optional exam for which high-performing students may receive some credit towards their college coursework, depending on which college or university they attend.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://apstudent.collegeboard.org/creditandplacement | title = Credit & Placement | work = AP Students | publisher = The [[College Board]] | year = 2017 | access-date = January 30, 2017}}</ref>
===Registration=== The AP examination for AP Physics C: Mechanics is separate from the AP examination for AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism. Before 2006, test-takers paid only once and were given the choice of taking either one or two parts of the Physics C test.
===Format=== The exam is configured in two categories: a 35-question [[multiple choice]] section and a 3-question [[free response]] section.<ref name=PhysCMechoverview/> Test takers are allowed to use an approved calculator during the entire exam.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://apstudent.collegeboard.org/apcourse/ap-physics-c-mechanics/calculator-and-table-policies | title = AP Physics C: Mechanics – Calculator and Table Policies | work = AP Students | publisher = [[College Board]] | year = 2017 | access-date = January 30, 2017}}</ref> The test is weighted such that each section is worth fifty percent (50%) of the final score.<ref name=PhysCMechoverview/> Additionally, tables of equations, information, and constants are provided for all portions of the exam as of 2015. This and [[AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism]] are the shortest AP exams, with total testing time of 90 minutes.<ref name=PhysCMechoverview/>
The topics covered by the exam are as follows:<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.collegeboard.com/student/testing/ap/physics_c/topics.html | title = Topic Outline | work = College Board Tests | publisher = The College Board | year = 2013 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130404054146/http://www.collegeboard.com/student/testing/ap/physics_c/topics.html | archive-date = April 4, 2013}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" !align="center"|Topic !align="center"|Percent |-align="center" |Kinematics |18% |-align="center" |Newton's laws of motion |20% |-align="center" |Work, energy, power |14% |-align="center" |Systems of particles, linear momentum |12% |-align="center" |Circular motion and rotation |18% |-align="center" |Oscillations and gravitation |18% |}

Distributions|url=http://www.totalregistration.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=471&Itemid=118|publisher=Total Registration|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> !2013<ref>{{citation | url = http://media.collegeboard.com/digitalServices/pdf/ap/apcentral/ap13_physics_C_M_ScoringDist.pdf | format = PDF | title = AP Physics C – Mechanics, Student Score Distributions – Global Distributions – May 2013 | year = 2013 | publisher = The [[College Board]] | access-date = January 30, 2017}}</ref> !2014<ref>{{cite web|last=Packer|first=Trevor|title=2014 AP Exam Score revision.text:
{{quote box|width=30em|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|quote="Accountants and the accountancy profession exist as a means of public service; the distinction which separates a profession from a mere means of livelihood is that the profession is accountable to standards of the public interest, and beyond the compensation paid by clients."|source=—Robert H. Montgomery, describing ethics in accounting in 2009<ref name="EthicalIssuesCA245">{{cite news|last=Love|first=Vincent J.|title=Understanding Accounting Ethics, Second Edition|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=1585902031&sid=2&Fmt=3&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|accessdate=May 18, 2009|date=October 1, 2008|publisher=''The CPA Journal''}}</ref>}} '''Accounting ethics''' is primarily a field of [[applied ethics]] and is part of [[business ethics]] and human [[ethics]], the study of [[moral value]]s and judgments as they apply to [[accountancy]]. It is an example of [[professional ethics]]. Accounting introduced by [[Luca Pacioli]], and later expanded by government groups, professional organizations, and independent companies. Ethics are taught in accounting courses at higher education institutions as well as by companies training [[accountant]]s and [[audit]]ors.
Due to the diverse range of accounting services and recent corporate collapses, attention has been drawn to ethical standards accepted within the accounting profession.<ref name="JackPercept">{{cite journal|last=Jackling|first=Beverly|author2=Barry J. Cooper|author3=Philomena Leung|author4=Steven Dellaportas|title=Professional Accounting Bodies' Perceptions of Ethical Issues, Causes of Ethical Failure and Ethics Education|journal=Managerial Auditing Journal|volume=22|issue=9|pages=928–944|year=2007|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=1347117971&sid=1&Fmt=3&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|accessdate=April 8, 2009|doi=10.1108/02686900710829426}}</ref> These collapses have resulted in a widespread disregard for the reputation of the accounting profession.<ref name="DellaDifference">{{cite journal|last=Dellaportas|first=Steven|title=Making a Difference with a Discrete Course on Accounting Ethics|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|volume=65|issue=4|pages=391–404|date=June 2006|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=1069642791&sid=13&Fmt=2&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|accessdate=April 8, 2009|doi=10.1007/s10551-006-0020-7}}</ref> To combat the criticism and prevent fraudulent accounting, various accounting organizations and governments have developed regulations and remedies for improved ethics among the accounting profession.
==Importance of ethics== The nature of the work carried out by accountants and auditors requires a high level of ethics. Shareholders, potential shareholders, and other users of the financial statements rely heavily on the yearly financial statements of a company as they can use this information to make an informed decision about investment.<ref name="FinReportShare">{{cite book|last=Alexander|first=David|author2=Anne Britton|title=Financial Reporting|publisher=Cengage Learning EMEA|year=2004|page=160|url=https://books.google.com/?id=1OUTXGDWeWoC&printsec=frontcover#PPA160,M1|isbn=1-84480-033-4}}</ref> They rely on the opinion of the accountants who prepared the statements, as well as the auditors that verified it, to present a true and fair view of the company.<ref name="AccAudRely">{{cite news|last=Dietz|first=David|title='Auditors Are Timid'|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KesNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QHADAAAAIBAJ&pg=2763,4354640&dq=investors+rely+on+accountants+auditors|date=April 26, 2002|publisher=''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''|accessdate=May 15, 2009}}</ref> Knowledge of ethics can help accountants and auditors to overcome ethical dilemmas, allowing for the right choice that, although it may not benefit the company, will benefit the public who relies on the accountant/auditor's reporting.<ref name="AcctEthicsBook">{{cite book|last=Duska|first=Ronald F.|author2=Brenda Shay Duska|title=Accounting Ethics|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|year=2003|page=28|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Y4LgVJgynCsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Understanding+Accounting+Ethics|isbn=0-631-21651-0}}</ref>
Most countries have differing focuses on enforcing accounting laws. In Germany, accounting legislation is governed by "tax law"; in Sweden, by "accounting law"; and in the United Kingdom, by the "[[United Kingdom company law|company law]]". In addition, countries have their own organizations which regulate accounting. For example, Sweden has the Bokföringsnämden (BFN - Accounting Standards Board), Spain the Instituto de Comtabilidad y Auditoria de Cuentas (ICAC), and the United States the [[Financial Accounting Standards Board]] (FASB).<ref name="EthicalIssuesAcct">{{cite book|last=Gowthorpe|first=Catherine|author2=John Blake|title=Ethical Issues in Accounting|year=1998|publisher=[[Routledge]]|page=7|isbn=0-415-17173-3}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Pacioli.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A painting of two men. The man at the center is looking off to his right while drawing a symbol with his right hand. His left hand is resting on a page in a book. He is wearing a robe with a hood. The man on the right is looking towards the front and is wearing a long-sleeve red shirt with a black jacket. Several writing utensils and books are on a table with a green tablecloth in the front of the image.|Luca Pacioli, here in [[Portrait of Luca Pacioli|a 1495 portrait by an unknown Renaissance artist]], wrote on accounting ethics in 1494.]] [[Luca Pacioli]], the "Father of Accounting", wrote on accounting ethics in his first book {{lang|la|[[Summa de arithmetica|Summa de arithmetica, geometria, proportioni, et proportionalita]]}}, published in 1494.<ref name="PacioliEthics">{{cite web|last=Smith |first=L. Murphy |title=Luca Pacioli: The Father of Accounting |url=http://acct.tamu.edu/smith/ethics/pacioli.htm |date=October 1, 2008 |publisher=[[Texas A&M University]] |accessdate=April 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818055709/http://acct.tamu.edu/smith/ethics/pacioli.htm |archivedate=August 18, 2011 }}</ref> Ethical standards have since then been developed through government groups, professional organizations, and independent companies. These various groups have led accountants to follow several codes of ethics to perform their duties in a professional work environment. Accountants must follow the code of ethics set out by the professional body of which they are a member. United States accounting societies such as the [[Association of Government Accountants]], [[Institute of Internal Auditors]], and the National Association of Accountants all have codes of ethics, and many accountants are members of one or more of these societies.<ref name="Loeb322">{{cite journal|last=Loeb|first=Stephen E.|title=Teaching Students Accounting Ethics: Some Crucial Issues|journal=Issues in Accounting Education|volume=3|pages=316–329|date=Fall 1988|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=7569002&sid=1&Fmt=7&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|accessdate=April 7, 2009}}</ref>
In 1887, the American Association of Public Accountants (AAPA) was created; it was the first step in developing professionalism in the United States accounting industry.<ref name="EvolutionEthics">{{cite book|last=Casler|first=Darwin J.|title=The Evolution of CPA Ethics: A Profile of Professionalization|publisher=[[Michigan State University]]|year=1964|page=5}}</ref> By 1905, the AAPA's first ethical codes were formulated to educate its members.<ref name="CriticalPerspectives209">{{cite book|editor=J. Edward Ketz|title=Accounting Ethics: Critical Perspectives on Business and Management|last=Preston|first=Alistair M.|author2=David J. Cooper|author3= D. Paul Scarbrough|author4=Robert C. Chilton|type =''Changes in the Code of Ethics of the U.S. Accounting Profession, 1917 and 1988''|publisher=Routledge|year=2006|page=209|isbn=0-415-35078-6}}</ref> During its twentieth anniversary meeting in October 1907, ethics was a major topic of the conference among its members. As a result of discussions, a list of professional ethics was incorporated into the organization's bylaws. However, because membership to the organization was voluntary, the association could not require individuals to conform to the suggested behaviors.<ref name="EvolutionEthics"/> Other accounting organizations, such as the Illinois Institute of Accountants, also pursued discussion on the importance of ethics for the field.<ref name="IllInsEthics">{{cite news|title=Bookkeepers Repel Inference That Their Own Employers Were Aimed At.|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/403309611.html?dids=403309611:403309611&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Feb+28%2C+1907&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=DISCUSS+ACCOUNTING+ETHICS.&pqatl=google|format = Fee required|accessdate=December 14, 2010|date=February 28, 1907|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]}}</ref> The AAPA was renamed several times throughout its history, before becoming the [[American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]] (AICPA) as it's named today. The AICPA developed five divisions of ethical principles that its members should follow: "independence, integrity, and objectivity"; "competence and technical standards"; "responsibilities to clients"; "responsibilities to colleagues"; as well as "other responsibilities and practices".<ref name="Perceptions5">{{cite book|last=Sellers|first=James H.|title=Accounting Student Perceptions of Business and Professional Ethics|publisher=[[University of Mississippi]]|year=1981|page=1}}</ref> Each of these divisions provided guidelines on how a [[Certified Public Accountant]] (CPA) should act as a professional. Failure to comply with the guidelines could have caused an accountant to be barred from practicing. When developing the ethical principles, the AICPA also considered how the profession would be viewed by those outside of the accounting industry.<ref name="Perceptions5"/>
==Teaching ethics== Courses on this subject have grown significantly in the last couple of decades.<ref name="EthicsPays"/> Teaching accountants about ethics can involve role playing, lectures, case studies, guest lectures, as well as other mediums.<ref name="Loeb322"/> Recent studies indicate that nearly all accounting textbooks touch on ethics in some way.<ref name="LoebResearch4">{{cite journal|last=Loeb|first=Stephen E.|title=Issues Relating to Teaching Accounting Ethics: An 18 Year Retrospective|journal=Research and Professional Responsibility and Ethics in Accounting|volume=11|page=4|year=2007|url=https://books.google.com/?id=bW5PXF3I0HwC&pg=PA31&dq=%22accounting+ethics%22#PPA4,M1|isbn=978-0-7623-1367-9|accessdate=May 14, 2009|doi=10.1016/s1574-0765(06)11001-8}}</ref> In 1993, the first United States center that focused on the study of ethics in the accounting profession opened at [[Binghamton University]].<ref name="AnonCenterEthics">{{cite journal|author=Anonymous|title=First Center to Study Accounting Ethics Opens|journal=Journal of Accountancy|volume=176|issue=4|page=19|date=October 1993|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=558663&sid=3&Fmt=3&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|accessdate=April 7, 2009}}</ref> Starting in 1999, several U.S. states began requiring ethics classes prior to taking the [[Uniform Certified Public Accountant Examination|CPA exam]].<ref name="LoebResearch4"/><ref>[http://www.cpeasy.com/ethics-cpe-courses/index.aspx "State Regulatory Accounting Ethics"] retrieved April 26, 2012.</ref>
{{quote box|width=35em|bgcolor=|quote='''Seven goals of accounting ethics education''' *Relate accounting education to moral issues. *Recognize issues in accounting that have ethical implications. *Develop "a sense of moral obligation" or responsibility. *Develop the abilities needed to deal with ethical conflicts or dilemmas. *Learn to deal with the uncertainties of the accounting profession. *"Set the stage for" a change in ethical behavior. *Appreciate and understand the history and composition of all aspects of accounting ethics and their relationship to the general field of ethics. —Stephen E. Loeb<ref name="Loeb322"/>}}
In 1988, Stephen E. Loeb proposed that accounting ethics education should include seven goals (adapted from a list by Daniel Callahan).<ref name="Loeb322"/> To implement these goals, he pointed out that accounting ethics could be taught throughout accounting curriculum or in an individual class tailored to the subject. Requiring it be taught throughout the curriculum would necessitate all accounting teachers to have knowledge on the subject (which may require training). A single course has issues as to where to include the course in a student's education (for example, before preliminary accounting classes or near the end of a student's degree requirements), whether there is enough material to cover in a semester class, and whether most universities have room in a four-year curriculum for a single class on the subject.<ref name="Loeb322"/>
There has been debate on whether ethics should be taught in a university setting. Supporters point out that ethics are important to the profession, and should be taught to accountants entering the field.<ref name="ForgotStake">{{cite news|last=Bernardi|first=Richard A.|author2=David F. Bean|title=Ethics in Accounting Education: The Forgotten Stakeholders|url=http://www.nysscpa.org/cpajournal/2006/706/essentials/p56.htm|date=July 2006|publisher=''The CPA Journal''|accessdate=May 14, 2009}}</ref> In addition, the education would help to reinforce students' ethical values and inspire them to prevent others from making unethical decisions.<ref name="EthicsPays">{{cite news|last=Vogel|first=David|title=Manager's Journal: Could an Ethics Course Have Kept Ivan From Going Bad?|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=27286496&sid=1&Fmt=3&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|date=April 27, 1987|publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''|accessdate=May 17, 2009}}</ref> Critics argue that an individual is ethical or not, and that teaching an ethics course would serve no purpose.<ref name="ForgotStake"/><ref name="DoTheyWork">{{cite news|last=Bean|first=David F.|author2=Richard A. Bernardi|title=Accounting Ethics Courses: Do They Work?|url=http://www.nysscpa.org/cpajournal/2007/107/essentials/p64.htm|date=January 2007|publisher=''The CPA Journal''|accessdate=May 17, 2009}}</ref> Despite opposition, instruction on accounting ethics by universities and conferences, has been encouraged by professional organizations and accounting firms.<ref name="Loeb199178">{{cite journal|last=Loeb|first=Stephen E.|title=The Evaluation of "Outcomes" of Accounting Ethics Education|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|volume=10|issue=2|pages=77–84|date=Fall 1991 |url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=572455&sid=1&Fmt=2&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|accessdate=April 7, 2009|doi=10.1007/BF00383611}}</ref> The Accounting Education Change Commission (AECC) has called for students to "know and understand the ethics of the profession and be able to make value-based judgments."<ref name="PostEnronAge2">{{cite book|last=Stuart|first=Iris|title=Ethics in the Post-Enron Age|publisher=SouthWestern/Thomson|year=2004|page=2|isbn=0-324-19193-6}}</ref>
Phillip G. Cottel argued that in order to uphold strong ethics, an accountant "must have a strong sense of values, the ability to reflect on a situation to determine the ethical implications, and a commitment to the well-being of others."<ref name="PracticalGuideProf">{{cite book|last=Cottel|first=Philip G.|title=Accounting Ethics: A Practical Guide for Professionals|publisher=Quorum Books|year=1990|pages=78–79|isbn=0-89930-401-X}}</ref> Iris Stuart recommends an ethics model consisting of four steps: the accountant must recognize that an ethical dilemma is occurring; identify the parties that would be interested in the outcome of the dilemma; determine alternatives and evaluate its effect on each alternative on the interested parties; and then select the best alternative.<ref name="PostEnronAge6">{{cite book|last=Stuart|first=Iris|title=Ethics in the Post-Enron Age|publisher=SouthWestern/Thomson|year=2004|page=6|isbn=0-324-19193-6}}</ref>
==Accounting scandals== {{main|Accounting scandals}} Accounting ethics has been deemed difficult to control as accountants and auditors must consider the interest of the public (which relies on the information gathered in audits) while ensuring that they remained employed by the company they are auditing.<ref name="Loeb322"/><ref name="WSJWhatYouLike">{{cite news|last=Berton|first=Lee|title=Goal: Ethical Standards for Accounting Practices|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=27058245&sid=1&Fmt=3&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|date=May 24, 1984|publisher=''[[Wall Street Journal]]''|accessdate=April 7, 2009}}</ref> They must consider how to best apply accounting standards even when faced with issues that could cause a company to face a significant loss or even be discontinued. Due to several accounting scandals within the profession, critics of accountants have stated that when asked by a client "what does two plus two equal?" the accountant would be likely to respond "what would you like it to be?".<ref name="WSJWhatYouLike"/> This thought process along with other criticisms of the profession's issues with conflict of interest, have led to various increased standards of professionalism while stressing ethics in the work environment.
The role of accountants is critical to society. Accountants serve as financial reporters and intermediaries in the capital markets and owe their primary obligation to the public interest. The information they provide is crucial in aiding managers, investors and others in making critical economic decisions. Accordingly, ethical improprieties by accountants can be detrimental to society, resulting in distrust by the public and disruption of efficient capital market operations.
{{quote box|width=30em|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|quote="Every company in the country is fiddling its profits. Every set of published accounts is based on books which have been gently cooked or completely roasted. The figures which are fed twice a year to the investing public have all been changed in order to protect the guilty. It is the biggest con trick since the [[Trojan horse]]. ... In fact this deception is all in perfectly good taste. It is totally legitimate. It is creative accounting."|source=—Ian Griffiths in 1986, describing [[creative accounting]]<ref name="BlakeGowthorpe2005">{{cite book|author1=John Blake|author2=Catherine Gowthorpe|title=Ethical Issues in Accounting|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8qtbh7PSFqQC&pg=PA24|date=20 June 2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1-134-69451-2}}</ref> }} From the 1980s to the present there have been multiple accounting scandals that were widely reported on by the media and resulted in fraud charges, bankruptcy protection requests, and the closure of companies and accounting firms. The scandals were the result of [[creative accounting]], misleading [[financial analysis]], as well as [[bribe]]ry. Various companies had issues with fraudulent accounting practices, including [[Nugan Hand Bank#Scandal and collapse|Nugan Hand Bank]], [[Phar-Mor#Bankruptcy|Phar-Mor]], [[WorldCom#Accounting scandals|WorldCom]], and [[American International Group#Accounting fraud claims|AIG]]. One of the most widely reported violation of accounting ethics involved [[Enron]], a multinational company, that for several years had not shown a true or fair view of their financial statements. Their auditor [[Arthur Andersen]], an accounting firm considered one of the "[[Big Four auditors|Big Five]]", signed off on the validity of the accounts despite the inaccuracies in the financial statements.<ref name="AASignOff">{{cite news|title=Auditors: In the palm of the banks?|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article5580824.ece|date=January 25, 2009|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|accessdate=June 18, 2009 | location=London | first1=Iain | last1=Dey | first2=Dominic | last2=Rushe}}</ref> When the unethical activities were reported, not only did Enron dissolve but Arthur Andersen also went out of business. Enron's shareholders lost [[USD|$]]25 billion as a result of the company's bankruptcy.<ref name="25BEnron">{{cite news|title=Enron Shareholders' Move Against Banks Is Rebuffed by Judge|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/28/business/enron-shareholders-move-against-banks-is-rebuffed-by-judge.html|date=February 28, 2003|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|accessdate=June 18, 2009}}</ref> Although only a fraction of Arthur Anderson's employees were involved with the scandal, the closure of the firm resulted in the loss of 85,000 jobs.<ref name="WP85000Jobs">{{cite news|last=Rosenwald|first=Michael S.|title=Extreme (Executive) Makeover|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/09/AR2007090901619_pf.html|date=September 10, 2007|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=April 7, 2009}}</ref><ref name="FallAnderson">{{cite news|last=Alexander|first=Delroy|author2=Greg Burns|author3=Robert Manor|author4=Flynn McRoberts|author5= E.A. Torriero|title=The Fall of Andersen|url=http://www.courant.com/news/nationworld/chi-0209010315sep01,0,2343149.story|date=September 1, 2002|publisher=''[[Hartford Courant]]''|accessdate=April 7, 2009}}</ref>
===Causes=== Fraudulent accounting can arise from a variety of issues. These problems usually come to light eventually and could ruin not only the company but also the auditors for not discovering or revealing the misstatements. Several studies have proposed that a firm's [[corporate culture]] as well as the values it stresses may negatively alter an accountant's behavior.<ref name="ClikeTrust">{{cite journal|last=Clikeman|first=Paul M.|title=Educating for the Public Trust|journal=The CPA Journal|volume=73|issue=8|page=80|date=August 2003|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=407305991&sid=3&Fmt=3&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|accessdate=April 7, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090511003019/http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=407305991&sid=3&Fmt=3&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD| archivedate= 11 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="AppleClimate">{{cite journal|last=Appelbaum|first=Steven H.|author2=Kyle J Deguire |author3=Mathieu Lay|title=The Relationship of Ethical Climate to Deviant Workplace Behaviour|journal=Corporate Governance|volume=5|issue=4|pages=43–55|year=2005|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=914821791&sid=5&Fmt=4&clientId=17862&RQT=309&VName=PQD|format = Registration required|accessdate=April 8, 2009| doi=10.1108/14720700510616587}}</ref> This environment could contribute to the degradation of ethical values that were learned from universities.<ref name="JackPercept"/>
Until 1977, ethics rules prevented accounting and auditing firms from advertising to clients. When the rules were lifted, spending by the largest CPA firms on advertisements rose from [[United States dollar|US$]]4 million in the 1980s to more than $100 million in the 2000s.<ref name="CSTAdvertise">{{cite news|last=Berton|first=Lee|title=Advertising has hurt accounting's ethics: critics|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1464160.html|format = Registration required|date=May 24, 1984|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|accessdate=April 7, 2009}}</ref> Critics claimed that, by allowing the firms to advertise, the business side overstepped the professional side of the profession, which led to a conflict of interest. This focus allowed for occurrences of fraud, and caused the firms, according to Apj , "... to offer services that made them more consultants and business advisers than auditors."<ref name="CSTAdvertise"/> As accounting firms became less interested in the lower-paying audits due to more focus on higher earning services such as consulting, problems arose.<ref name="WashPost1998">{{cite news|last=Crenshaw|first=Albert B.|author2=Brett D. Fromson|title=A Conflict for CPAs?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/business/longterm/ethics/ethics3.htm|date=March 29, 1998|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=April 8, 2009}}</ref> This disregard for the lack of time spent on audits resulted in a lack of attention to catching creative and fraudulent accounting.<ref name="BizJourBoil">{{cite news|last=Somerville|first=Leigh|title=Accounting Changes Boil Down to Principles vs. Rules|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triad/stories/2003/03/03/focus2.html|date=February 28, 2003|publisher=''[[The Business Journal]]''|accessdate=April 8, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090511233016/http://www.bizjournals.com/triad/stories/2003/03/03/focus2.html| archivedate= 11 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
A 2007 article in ''Managerial Auditing Journal'' determined the top nine factors that contributed to ethical failures for accountants based on a survey of 66 members of the [[International Federation of Accountants]]. The factors include (in order of most significant): "self-interest, failure to maintain objectivity and independence, inappropriate professional judgment, lack of ethical sensitivity, improper leadership and ill-culture, failure to withstand advocacy threats, lack of competence, lack of organizational and peer support, and lack of professional body support."<ref name="JackPercept"/> The main factor, self-interest, is the motivation by an accountant to act in his/her best interest or when facing a conflict of interest.<ref name="JackPercept"/> For example, if an auditor has an issue with an account he/she is auditing, but is receiving financial incentives to ignore these issues, the auditor may act unethically.
====Principles and rules==== {{quote box|width=30em|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|quote="When people need a doctor, or a lawyer, or a certified public accountant, they seek someone whom they can trust to do a good job — not for himself, but for them. They have to trust him, since they cannot appraise the quality of his 'product'. To trust him they must believe that he is competent, and that his primary motive is to help them."|source=—John L. Carey, describing ethics in accounting<ref name="CriticalPerspectives11">{{cite book|editor=J. Edward Ketz|title=Accounting Ethics: Critical Perspectives on Business and Management|publisher=Routledge|year=2006|page=11|isbn=0-415-35078-6}}</ref>}} The [[International Financial Reporting Standards]] (IFRS) are standards and interpretations developed by the [[International Accounting Standards Board]], which are principle-based.<ref name="WSJSwitch">{{cite news|last=Scannell|first=Kara|author2=Joanna Slater|title=SEC Moves To Pull Plug On U.S. Accounting Standards|url=http://s.wsj.net/article/SB121985665095476825.html?mod=fpa_whatsnews|date=August 28, 2008|publisher=''[[Wall Street Journal]]''|accessdate=April 8, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090511112508/http://s.wsj.net/article/SB121985665095476825.html?mod=fpa_whatsnews| archivedate= 11 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> IFRS are used by over 115 countries or areas including the [[European Union]], Australia, and Hong Kong.<ref name="IFRSList">{{cite web|title=Use of IFRSs by Jurisdiction|url=http://www.iasplus.com/country/useias.htm#totals|date=March 24, 2009|publisher=[[International Financial Reporting Standards|IAS]] |accessdate=April 8, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090512150619/http://www.iasplus.com/country/useias.htm| archivedate= 12 May 2009 <!--DASHBot--> |deadurl=no}}</ref> The United States [[Generally Accepted Accounting Principles]] (GAAP), the standard framework of guidelines for financial accounting, is largely rule-based.<ref name="WSJSwitch"/> Critics have stated that the rules-based GAAP is partly responsible for the number of scandals that the United States has suffered.<ref name="BizJourBoil"/> The principles-based approach to monitoring requires more professional judgment than the rules-based approach.<ref name="BennettRules">{{cite journal |url=http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=907368 |last=Bennett |first=Bruce |author2=Michael Bradbury |author3=Helen Pragnell |title=Rules, Principles and Judgments in Accounting Standards |journal=Abacus |volume=42 |issue=2 |pages=189–203 |year=2006 |format=Registration required |ssrn=907368 |doi=10.1111/j.1467-6281.2006.00197.x |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511192601/http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=907368 |archivedate=11 May 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=10 July 2017}}</ref>
There are many stakeholders in many countries such as The United States who report several concerns in the usage of rules-based accounting. According to recent studies, many believe that the principles-based approach in financial reporting would not only improve but would also support an auditor upon dealing with client’s pressure. As a result, financial reports could be viewed with fairness and transparency. When the U.S. switched to International accounting standards, they are composed that this would bring change. However, as a new chairperson of the SEC takes over the system, the transition brings a stronger review about the pros and cons of rules- based accounting. While the move towards international standards progresses, there are small amount of research that examines the effect of principle- based standards in an auditor’s decision- making process. According to 114 auditing experts, most are willing to allow clients to manage their net income based on rules- based standards. These results offers insight to the SEC, IASB and FASB in weighing the arguments in the debate of principles- vs. rules based- accounting.<ref>{{cite web|last=Segovia|first=Joann|title=Do Principles- vs. Rules-Based Standards Have a Differential Impact on U.S. Auditors' Decisions?|url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=1871151361&sid=1&Fmt=2&clientId=31810&RQT=309&VName=PQD|accessdate=October 29, 2011}}</ref>
IFRS is based on "understandability, relevance, materiality, reliability, and comparability".<ref name="RRCUMIFRS">{{cite book|last=Tosen|first=Graeme|title=A Practical Guide to IFRS for Derivatives and Structured Finance|publisher=Euromoney Books|year=2006|page=134|url=https://books.google.com/?id=00Jco44doU0C&pg=PA134&lpg=PA134&dq=relevance,+reliability,+comparability,+understandability,+and+materiality+IFRS|isbn=1-84374-267-5}}</ref> Since IFRS has not been adopted by all countries, these practices do not make the international standards viable in the world domain. In particular, the United States has not yet conformed and still uses GAAP which makes comparing principles and rules difficult. In August 2008, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) proposed that the United States switch from GAAP to IFRS, starting in 2014.<ref name="WSJSwitch"/>
===Responses to scandals=== Since the major accounting scandals, new reforms, regulations, and calls for increased higher education have been introduced to combat the dangers of unethical behavior.<ref name="PerfReport17">{{cite book|last=Johnsson|first=Hans|author2=Per Erik Kihlstedt|title=Performance-Based Reporting|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2005|page=17|url=https://books.google.com/?id=T2sIinuZlHIC&pg=PA9&dq=%22accounting+ethics%22|isbn=0-471-73543-4}}</ref> By educating accountants on ethics before entering the workforce, such as through higher education or initial training at companies, it is believed it will help to improve the credibility of the accounting profession.<ref name="DellaDifference"/> Companies and accounting organizations have expanded their assistance with educators by providing education materials to assist professors in educating students.<ref name="BizJourChampion">{{cite news|last=Mader|first=Becca|title=Enron case causes colleges to champion accounting ethics|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/stories/2002/05/06/focus1.html|date=May 3, 2002|publisher=''[[The Business Journal]]''|accessdate=April 8, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090523034641/http://www.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/stories/2002/05/06/focus1.html| archivedate= 23 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
New regulations in response to the scandals include the [[Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Act 2004]] in Australia as well as the [[Sarbanes-Oxley Act]] of 2002, developed by the United States.<ref name="JackPercept"/> Sarbanes-Oxley limits the level of work which can be carried out by accounting firms. In addition, the Act put a limit on the fee which a firm can receive from one client as a percentage of their total fees. This ensures that companies are not wholly reliant on one firm for its income, in the hope that they do not need to act unethically to keep a steady income. The act also protects [[whistleblower]]s and requires senior management in public companies to sign off on the accuracy of its company's [[accounting records]]. In 2002, the five members of the [[Public Oversight Board]] (POB), which oversaw ethics within the accounting profession, resigned after critics deemed the board ineffective and the SEC proposed developing a new panel, the [[Public Company Accounting Oversight Board]] (PCAOB).<ref name="5PCAOB">{{cite news|last=Labaton|first=Stephen|title=Accounting Ethics Panel Members Resign, Rejecting Sec Chief's Plan|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YuwNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=M3ADAAAAIBAJ&pg=3645,467306&dq=accounting+ethics|date=January 23, 2002|publisher=''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''|accessdate=April 8, 2009}}</ref> The PCAOB was developed through the Act, and replaced the POB.<ref name="ManagerialAcctBook">{{cite book|last=Hilton|first=Ronald W.|title=Managerial Accounting: Creating Value in a Dynamic Business Environment|publisher=McGraw Hill/Irwin|location=Boston|edition=Sixth|year=2005|page=26|isbn=0-07-111314-2}}</ref>
In 2003, the [[International Federation of Accountants]] (IFAC) released a report entitled ''Rebuilding Public Confidence in Financial Reporting: An International Perspective''.<ref name="IFARebuild">{{cite news|last=Crow |first=John |author2=Christian Aubin |author3=Olivia Kirtley |author4=Kosuke Nakahira |author5=Ian Ramsay |author6=Guylaine Saucier |author7=Graham Ward |title=Rebuilding Public Confidence in Financial Reporting: An International Perspective |url=http://www.ifac.org/Credibility/ViewPoints_PubDL.php?PubID=00061 |format=PDF |date=August 2003 |publisher=[[International Federation of Accountants]] |accessdate=April 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090528233709/http://www.ifac.org/Credibility/ViewPoints_PubDL.php?PubID=00061 |archivedate=May 28, 2009 }}</ref> By studying the international company collapses as a result of accounting issues, it determined areas for improvement within organizations as well as recommendations for companies to develop more effective ethics codes. The report also recommended that companies pursue options that would improve training and support so accountants could better handle ethical dilemmas.<ref name="JackPercept"/> A collaborative effort by members of the international financial regulatory community led by [[Michel Prada]], Chairman of the French Financial Markets Authority, resulting in establishment of the [[Public Interest Oversight Board]] (PIOB) on 1 March 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bis.org/press/p050228.htm |publisher=Bank for International Settlements |accessdate=2011-06-07 |title=International regulators and related organizations announce the Public Interest Oversight Board (PIOB) for the international accountancy profession |date=28 February 2005| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110606162818/http://www.bis.org/press/p050228.htm| archivedate= 6 June 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The PIOB provides oversight of the IFAC standards-setting boards: the [[International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board]] (IAASB), the [[International Accounting Education Standards Board]] (IAESB) and the [[International Ethics Standards Board for Accountants]] (IESBA).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ifac.org/About/PIOB.php |title=Public Interest Oversight Board |publisher=IFAC |accessdate=2011-06-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110714060634/http://www.ifac.org/About/PIOB.php| archivedate= 14 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The most recent reform came into effect in July 2010 when President Obama signed "The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act". The act covers a broad range of changes. The highlights of the legislation are consumer protections with authority and independence, ends too big to fail bail outs, advance warning system, transparency and accountability for exotic instruments, executive compensation and corporate governance, protects investors, and enforces regulations on the books.<ref><http://banking.senate.gov/public/_files/070110_Dodd_Frank_Wall_Street_Reform_comprehensive_summary_Final.pdf {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100710034423/http://banking.senate.gov/public/_files/070110_Dodd_Frank_Wall_Street_Reform_comprehensive_summary_Final.pdf |date=2010-07-10 }}>.</ref> The legislation also resulted in the Office of the Whistleblower, which was established to administer the SEC's whistleblower program. Congress authorized the SEC to provide monetary awards to whistleblowers who come forward with information that results in a minimum of a $1,000,000 sanction. The rewards are between 10% and 30% of the dollar amount collected.<ref>"Welcome to the Office of the Whistleblower." U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (Home Page). Web. 31 Oct. 2011. <https://www.sec.gov/whistleblower>.</ref> Whistleblowers help identify fraud and other unethical behaviors early on. The result is less harm to investors, quickly holding offenders responsible, and to maintain the integrity of the U.S. markets.

New York: Arno Press, 1980. {{ISBN|0-405-13506-8}}. *Carey, John L. William O. Doherty. ''Ethical Standards of the Accounting Profession''. New York: Garland Pub., 1986. {{ISBN|0-8240-7877-2}}. *Cheffers, Mark. Michael Pakaluk. ''Understanding Accounting Ethics''. Allen David Press, 2007. {{ISBN|0-9765280-0-2}}. *Cottell Jr., Philip G. Terry M. Perlin. ''Accounting Ethics: A Practical Guide for Professionals''. New York: Quorum Books, 1990. {{ISBN|0-89930-401-X}}. *Davis, Michael. Andrew Stark. ''Conflict of Interest in the Professions''. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|0-19-512863-X}}. *Guy, Dan M. D.R. Carmichael, Linda A. Lach. ''Ethics for CPAs: Meeting Expectations in Challenging Times''. Hoboken, NJ: Wiley, 2003. {{ISBN|0-471-27176-4}}. *Hoffman, W. Michael. ''The Ethics of Accounting and Finance: Trust, Responsibility, and Control''. Westport, CT: Quorum Books, 1996. {{ISBN|0-89930-997-6}}. *Mills, Daniel Quinn. ''Wheel, Deal, and Steal: Deceptive Accounting, Deceitful CEOs, and Ineffective Reforms''. Upper Saddle River, NJ: FT/Prentice Hall, 2003. {{ISBN|0-13-140804-6}}. *Williams, J., and R. Elson. "IMPROVING ETHICAL EDUCATION IN THE ACCOUNTING PROGRAM: A CONCEPTUAL COURSE. " Academy of Educational Leadership Journal 14.4 (2010): 107-116. ABI/INFORM Global, ProQuest. Web. 30 Oct. 2011.

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Married Women's Property Act]] (link changed to [[Married Women's Property Act 1870]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{hatnote|Adelaide Manning is also a real name of [[Manning Coles]]}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = Adelaide Manning |image = Elizabeth Adelaide Manning.jpg |image_size = |caption = portrait at Girton College |birth_name = Elizabeth Adelaide Manning |birth_date = 1828 |birth_place = [[Bloomsbury]], London, England |death_date = 10 August {{death year and age|1905|1828}} |death_place = Kensington, London |education = Bedford College and Girton College |parents = [[James Manning (lawyer)|James Manning]] |relatives = [[Charlotte Manning]] (step-mother) |nationality = British }}
'''Elizabeth Adelaide Manning''' (1828 – 10 August 1905) was a British writer and editor. She championed [[kindergarten]]s. She was one of the first students to attend [[Girton College]]. Manning was active for the [[National Indian Association]] which championed education and the needs of women in India.
==Life== Elizabeth Adelaide Manning was born in 1828. Her mother was Clarissa (born Palmer) and her father was the lawyer [[James Manning (lawyer)|James Manning]], who helped the [[Law Amendment Society]] decide to support changing the [[Married Women's Property Act 1870|law relating to married women's property]].<ref name=odnb/>
Manning was a founder member of the [[National Froebel Foundation|London Froebel Society]] in 1874 with her cousin [[Caroline Bishop (kindergarten)|Caroline Bishop]]. Bishop was advising the [[London School Board]] on the use of [[Kindergarten]] methods and Manning presented a paper on the same subject to the Social Science Association. The following year the Froebel Society became national.<ref name=odnb/> She was one of the first students to attend [[Girton College]] after she sat the entrance exam. Her stepmother was briefly the first mistress.<ref name=odnb/>
In February 1871 Manning and her stepmother started the London branch of the [[National Indian Association]].<ref name=open>[http://www.open.ac.uk/researchprojects/makingbritain/content/elizabeth-adelaide-manning Elizabeth Adelaide Manning], Open University. Retrieved 25 July 2015</ref> Her stepmother died the following month and Manning increasingly became the society's main proponent. She edited its magazine, whose title shifted from ''The Journal of the National Indian Association'' to ''The Indian Magazine'' in 1886, and then in 1891 ''The Indian Magazine and Review'', still under Manning's leadership.<ref name=open/>
In 1882 the NIA launched Medical Women for India, an initiative to train women doctors so that they could work in part on caring for women in India. (See [[Zenana missions]].) The NIA also took an interest in students from India who were studying in Britain. Manning created a book of guidance called ''Handbook of information relating to university and professional studies etc. for Indian students in the United Kingdom''. Manning had an open house policy and she cared particularly for students from India. In 1888 [[Cornelia Sorabji]] contacted the NIA from India for assistance in completing university education.<ref name=mary/> This letter was championed by [[Mary Hobhouse (died 1905)|Mary Hobhouse]] and Manning contributed funds, as did [[Florence Nightingale]], Sir [[William Wedderburn]] and others.<ref name=mary/> Sorabji arrived in England in 1889 and stayed with Manning.<ref name=mary/> Sorabji was the first woman to complete a law degree at Oxford and she kept contact with the NIA during her career.<ref name=mary>[http://www.open.ac.uk/researchprojects/makingbritain/taxonomy/term/343 Mary Hobhouse], Open University. Retrieved 26 July 2015</ref>
In July 1904, Manning was awarded the [[Kaisar-i-Hind Medal]], first class, by the King for services to the [[British Raj]].<ref name="Office1819">{{cite book|author=Great Britain. India Office|title=The India List and India Office List for ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b2NPAAAAMAAJ|year=1819|publisher=Harrison and Sons|page=172}}</ref>
Manning died in London in 1905.<ref name=odnb>Gillian Sutherland, "Manning, (Elizabeth) Adelaide (1828–1905)", ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, May 2007 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/48424, accessed 25 July 2015]</ref><ref name=open/>
==Legacy== Manning left bequests to the NIA, The [[National Froebel Foundation|Froebel Society]], the [[Royal Free Hospital]] and [[Charles Voysey (theist)|Charles Voysey]]'s unorthodox church in Piccadilly.<ref name=odnb/> She left her medal and two thousand pounds (£2,000) to Girton College. A portrait of her (from a photograph) was given by Emily Davies to Girton College, and Manning also gave the college a portrait of her stepmother.<ref name="Stephen2010">{{cite book|first=Barbara|last=Stephen|title=Girton College 1869–1932|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cZmebitQs_cC&pg=PA186|date=17 June 2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-108-01531-8|pages=186–}}</ref> In 1911 Indian writer [[Sukumar Ray]] wrote home to his parents about the NIA, which he described as "'MissManning's Association". ?।
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Manning, Adelaide}} [[Category:1828 births]] [[Category:1905 deaths]] [[Category:Recipients of the Kaisar-i-Hind Medal]] [[Category:Writers from London]] [[Category:19th-century British writers]] [[Category:19th-century British women writers]] [[Category:Alumni of Bedford College (London)]] [[Category:Alumni of Girton College, Cambridge]] [[Category:British magazine editors]] [[Category:Social reformers]] [[Category:Education reform]] [[Category:British India]]

{{Lead too short|date=August 2018}} {{needs more references|date=August 2018}} '''Anti-schooling activism''' or '''radical education reform''' seeks to abolish [[compulsory education|compulsory schooling]] laws.
==Arguments==
===Teaching as political control===
A non-curriculum, non-instructional method of teaching was advocated by [[Neil Postman]] and Charles Weingartner in their book ''Teaching as a Subversive Activity''. In [[inquiry education]] students are encouraged to ask questions which are meaningful to them, and which do not necessarily have easy answers; teachers are encouraged to avoid giving answers.<ref>Postman, Neil, and Weingartner, Charles (1969), Teaching as a Subversive Activity, Dell, New York, NY.</ref>
[[Murray N. Rothbard]] argues that the history of the drive for [[compulsory schooling]] is not guided by altruism, but by a desire to coerce the population into a mold desired by "The Establishment".{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}{{clarify|date=July 2017}}
[[John Caldwell Holt]] asserts that youths should have the right to control and direct their own learning, and that the current compulsory schooling system violates a basic fundamental right of humans: the right to decide what enters our minds. He thinks that freedom of learning is part of [[freedom of thought]], even more fundamental a human right than [[freedom of speech]]. He especially states that forced schooling, regardless of whether the student is learning anything whatsoever, or if the student could more effectively learn elsewhere in different ways, is a gross violation of civil liberties (Holt, 1974).
[[Nathaniel Branden]] adduces government should not be permitted to remove children forcibly from their homes, with or without the parents' consent, and subject the children to educational training and procedures of which the parents may or may not approve. He also claims that citizens should not have their wealth expropriated to support an educational system which they may or may not sanction, and to pay for the education of children who are not their own. He claims this must be true for anyone who understands and is consistently committed to the principle of [[individual rights]]. He asserts that the disgracefully low level of education in America today is the predictable result of a state-controlled school system, and that the solution is to bring the field of education into the marketplace.<ref>Branden, N. (1963). Public Education, Should Education be Compulsory and Tax Supported, as it is Today? Chapter 5, Common Fallacies About Capitalism, [[Ayn Rand]], [[Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal]], p. 89.</ref>
===The corruption of children – Rousseau=== [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]] wrote in his book ''[[Emile: or, On Education]]'' that all children are perfectly designed organisms, ready to learn from their surroundings so as to grow into virtuous adults, but due to the malign influence of corrupt society, they often fail to do so. Rousseau advocated an educational method which consisted of removing the child from society—for example, to a country home—and alternately conditioning him through changes to environment and setting traps and puzzles for him to solve or overcome.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}
Rousseau was unusual in that he recognized and addressed the potential of a problem of legitimation for teaching. He advocated that adults always be truthful with children, and in particular that they never hide the fact that the basis for their authority in teaching was purely one of physical coercion: "I'm bigger than you." Once children reached the age of reason, at about 12, they would be engaged as free individuals in the ongoing process of their own.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}
===Grading – Illich=== In ''[[Deschooling Society]]'', [[Ivan Illich]] calls for the disestablishment of schools. He claims that schooling confuses teaching with learning, grades with education, diplomas with competence, attendance with attainment, and, especially, process with substance. He writes that schools do not reward real achievement, only processes. Schools inhibit a person’s will and ability to self-learn, ultimately resulting in psychological impotence. He claims that forced schooling perverts the victims’ natural inclination to grow and learn and replaces it with the demand for instruction. Further, the current model of schooling, replete with credentials, betrays the value of a self-taught individual. Moreover, institutionalized schooling seeks to quantify the unquantifiable – human growth.
=== Effects on local culture and economics === In some cases schooling has been used as a tool for assimilation and a both deliberate and inadvertent tool to change local culture and economics into another form. Opponents of this effect argue it is a human right for a culture to be maintained, and education can violate this human right.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/66455/|title=Indigenous education and human rights|last=Noam|first=Schimmel,|date=2007-01-01|website=eprints.lse.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref> Forced schooling has been used to forcibly assimilate Native Americans in the [[American Indian boarding schools|United States]] and [[Canadian Indian residential school system|Canada]], which some have said is [[cultural genocide]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/03/world/americas/canadas-forced-schooling-of-aboriginal-children-was-cultural-genocide-report-finds.html|title=Canada’s Forced Schooling of Aboriginal Children Was ‘Cultural Genocide,’ Report Finds|last=Austen|first=Ian|date=2015-06-02|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sagchip.org/ziibiwing/planyourvisit/pdf/aibscurrguide.pdf|title=American Indian Boarding Schools: An Exploration of Global Ethnic & Cultural Cleansing|last=Jones|first=Jennifer|last2=Bosworth|first2=Dee Ann|date=2011|website=|publisher=Ziibiwing Center of Anishinabe Culture & Lifeways|access-date=|last3=Lonetree|first3=Amy}}</ref> Many psychologists believe the forced assimilation of native cultures has contributed to their high suicide rates and poverty.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/feb07/astruggle.aspx|title='A struggle for hope'|website=apa.org|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref> Western education encourages Western modes of survival and economic systems, which can be worse and poorer than the existing modes of survival and economic systems of an existing culture.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://faculty.webster.edu/corbetre/philosophy/education/bg/bg-ch-5.html|title=Philosophy of Education -- From: Chapter 5: Schooling in Capitalist America|website=faculty.webster.edu|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eco-action.org/dt/affluent.html|title=neolithic hunter-gatherers: Marshall Sahlins- The Original Affluent Society|website=www.eco-action.org|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
=== School related stress and depression ===
There are many factors that can cause schooling to be source of [[Stress (psychology)|stress]] and [[Depression (mood)|depression]] in a person's life, which can have long term health effects<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schneiderman|first=Neil|last2=Ironson|first2=Gail|last3=Siegel|first3=Scott D.|date=2004-11-01|title=Stress and Health: Psychological, Behavioral, and Biological Determinants|url=http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/10.1146/annurev.clinpsy.1.102803.144141|journal=Annual Review of Clinical Psychology|volume=1|issue=1|pages=607–628|doi=10.1146/annurev.clinpsy.1.102803.144141|issn=1548-5943|pmc=2568977|pmid=17716101}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/03/opinion/sunday/is-the-drive-for-success-making-our-children-sick.html|title=Is the Drive for Success Making Our Children Sick?|last=Abeles|first=Vicki|date=2016-01-02|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> and mental disorders. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/freedom-learn/201001/the-decline-play-and-rise-in-childrens-mental-disorders|title=The Decline of Play and Rise in Children's Mental Disorders|last=Gray|first=Peter|date=2010-01-26|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> [[School bullying]] can lead to depression and long term emotional damage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mentalhelp.net/articles/the-long-term-effects-of-bullying/|title=The Long Term Effects of Bullying|website=www.mentalhelp.net|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> Societal and familial academic pressure and rigorous schooling can also lead to stress, depressions, and suicide.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/doublex/2015/07/helicopter_parenting_is_increasingly_correlated_with_college_age_depression.html|title=Kids of Helicopter Parents Are Sputtering Out|last=Lythcott-Haims|first=Julie|date=2015-07-05|newspaper=Slate|language=en-US|issn=1091-2339|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2013/12/02/246599742/school-stress-takes-a-toll-on-health-teens-and-parents-say|title=School Stress Takes A Toll On Health, Teens And Parents Say|newspaper=NPR.org|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> Academic pressure and rigorous schooling has been pointed to as a cause of the high rate of [[Suicide in South Korea|suicide among South Korean]] adolescents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2015/s4255647.htm|title=South Korean education success has its costs in unhappiness and suicide rates|date=2015-06-16|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dianeravitch.net/2014/08/03/why-we-should-not-copy-education-in-south-korea/|title=Why We Should Not Copy Education in South Korea|date=2014-08-03|website=Diane Ravitch's blog|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2015/04/28/Suicide-is-leading-cause-of-death-among-South-Korean-teens-says-report/3871430235561/|title=Suicide is leading cause of death among South Korean teens, says report|newspaper=UPI|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2015/04/15/393939759/the-all-work-no-play-culture-of-south-korean-education|title=The All-Work, No-Play Culture Of South Korean Education|newspaper=NPR.org|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> General boredom from school can also cause stress,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.psychologicalscience.org/news/releases/im-bored-research-on-attention-can-help-us-understand-the-unengaged-mind.html#.WC_hLqIrJE4|title="I’m Bored!" – Research on Attention Sheds Light on the Unengaged Mind|newspaper=Association for Psychological Science|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> and low academic performance can lead to low self esteem.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/doublex/2013/05/the_case_against_grades_they_lower_self_esteem_discourage_creativity_and.html|title=The Case Against Grades|last=Thomsen|first=Michael|date=2013-05-01|newspaper=Slate|language=en-US|issn=1091-2339|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> A student's family can suffer from academic related stress as well.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pressman|first=Robert M.|last2=Sugarman|first2=David B.|last3=Nemon|first3=Melissa L.|last4=Desjarlais|first4=Jennifer|last5=Owens|first5=Judith A.|last6=Schettini-Evans|first6=Allison|title=Homework and Family Stress: With Consideration of Parents’ Self Confidence, Educational Level, and Cultural Background|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/01926187.2015.1061407|journal=The American Journal of Family Therapy|volume=43|issue=4|pages=297–313|doi=10.1080/01926187.2015.1061407}}</ref> One psychologist states:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/freedom-learn/201408/the-danger-back-school|title=The Danger of Back to School|website=www.psychologytoday.com|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
=== Ineffective or counter to its purpose === Some of the proposed purposes of western style compulsory education are to prepare students to join the adult workforce and be financially successful, have students learn useful skills and knowledge, and prepare students to make positive economic or scientific contributions to society.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ascd.org/publications/newsletters/education-update/jul12/vol54/num07/What-Is-the-Purpose-of-Education%C2%A2.aspx|title=Education Update:Quality Feedback:What Is the Purpose of Education?|last=ASCD|website=www.ascd.org|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sec-ed.co.uk/best-practice/what-is-the-purpose-of-education/|title=What is the purpose of education?|website=www.sec-ed.co.uk|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> Critics of schooling say it is ineffective at achieving these purposes and goals. In many countries, schools do not keep up with the skills demanded by the workplace, or never have taught relevant skills.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/educationnews/11988756/Schools-failing-to-prepare-young-people-for-work-say-business-leaders.html|title=Schools 'failing to prepare young people for work', say business leaders|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/student/news/schools-are-too-focused-on-exam-results-and-dont-prepare-students-for-the-workplace-survey-finds-10469021.html|title=Schools 'are not preparing students for the workplace'|date=2015-08-24|newspaper=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thelocal.se/20130917/50294|title='Education inflation' hurts Swedes' job prospects|date=2013-09-17|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2014/09/03/robert_reich_college_is_a_ludicrous_waste_of_money_partner/|title=Robert Reich: College is a ludicrous waste of money|last=Reich|first=Robert|website=Salon|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> Students often feel unprepared for college as well.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://edsource.org/2015/survey-most-high-school-students-feel-unprepared-for-college-careers/83752|title=Survey: Most high school students feel unprepared for college, careers|website=EdSource|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> More schooling does not necessarily correlate with greater economic growth.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://educationnext.org/education-and-economic-growth/|title=Education and Economic Growth - Education Next|date=2008-02-29|newspaper=Education Next|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> Alternate forms of schooling, such as the [[Sudbury school|Sudbury model]], have been shown to be sufficient for college acceptance and other western cultural goals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sudval.org/05_alumni.html|title=Sudbury Valley School • Online Library. Alumni|last=|first=|date=|website=www.sudval.org|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
Instead of being a way out of poverty and a way to stay away from crime, for many, school has the opposite effect. Schooling often perpetuates poverty and class divisions.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/05/15/how-public-schools-demand-failure-and-perpetuate-poverty.html|title=How Public Schools Demand Failure and Perpetuate Poverty|last=Soling|first=Cevin|date=2016-05-15|website=The Daily Beast|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hochschild|first=Jennifer L.|date=2016-11-19|title=Social Class in Public Schools|url=http://scholar.harvard.edu/jlhochschild/publications/social-class-public-schools|journal=Journal of Social Issues|volume=59|issue=4}}</ref> At many schools, students are introduced to gangs, drugs and crime.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/ojjdp/183015.pdf|title=Youth Gangs in School|last=Howell|first=James|date=2000|work=Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention; Juvenile Justice Bulletin|last2=Lynch|first2=James|access-date=|via=}}</ref> The [[School-to-prison pipeline|school to prison pipeline]] also converts children into criminals through overly harsh punishments.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aclu.org/issues/juvenile-justice/school-prison-pipeline|title=School-to-Prison Pipeline|newspaper=American Civil Liberties Union|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> Punishments from truancy and other school related laws also adversely effect students and parents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://whatiscommoncore.wordpress.com/2013/07/23/compulsory-educations-unforeseen-consequences-nebraska-case-studies/|title=Compulsory Education’s Unforeseen Consequences: Nebraska Case Studies|date=2013-07-23|website=COMMON CORE|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/121186/truancy-laws-unfairly-attack-poor-children-and-parents|title=Inexcusable Absences|last=Goldstein|first=Dana|date=2015-03-06|website=New Republic|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://reason.com/archives/2015/06/06/jail-for-missed-days-at-school-the-madne|title=Jail for Missed Days at School? The Madness of Truancy Laws.|date=2015-06-06|newspaper=Reason.com|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
==See also== * [[John Taylor Gatto]] * [[John Holt (educator)]] * [[Philosophy of education]] * [[Sudbury model]] * [[Unschooling]] * [[Deschooling]] * [[Indigenous education#Criticisms of the Western educational model|Indigenous education § Criticism of the Western educational model]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
