revision.text:
{{COI|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox dot-com company | name = Udemy, Inc. | logo = UdemyLogo.svg | collapsible = yes | collapsetext = Screenshot | screenshot = Udemy screenshot.jpg | caption = | author = {{hlist |Eren Bali |Oktay Caglar| [[Gagan Biyani]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://about.udemy.com/company//|title=Our origins|date=2016-06-02|website=VentureBeat|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref><!--end hlist:-->}} | homepage = {{url|http://udemy.com}} | commercial = Yes | industry = [[e-learning]] | language = | registration = | foundation = {{Start date|2010}} | creators = {{unbulleted list|Eren Bali|[[Gagan Biyani]]||Oktay Caglar}} | key_people = Kevin H. Johnson ([[CEO]]) | current_status = Active | alexa = {{Increase}}404 ({{as of|2017|9|7|alt=September 2017}}) }}
'''Udemy.com''' is an online learning platform. It is aimed at professional adults.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fitzpatrick|first1=Alex|title=Udemy Thinks It’s Cracked the Future of Online Education|url=http://time.com/4215787/udemy-dennis-yang/|accessdate=25 September 2016|publisher=Time|date=February 12, 2016}}</ref> Unlike academic [[massive open online course]] (MOOC) programs which are driven by traditional collegiate coursework, Udemy uses content from online content creators to sell for profit.<ref name=techcrunch5-8-14>Lomas, Natasha. [https://techcrunch.com/2014/05/08/udemy-series-c/ Online Learning Marketplace Udemy Raises $32M To Scale Up Internationally]. ''TechCrunch''. May 8, 2014</ref> Udemy provides tools which enable users to create a course, promote it and earn money from student tuition charges.
No Udemy courses are currently credentialed for college credit; students take courses largely as a means of improving job-related skills.<ref name=techcrunch5-8-14 /> Some courses generate credit toward technical [[certification]]. Udemy has made a special effort to attract corporate trainers seeking to create coursework for employees of their company.<ref name=InfoWeek4-16-13>Carr, David F. [http://www.informationweek.com/software/udemy-comes-to-corporate-training/d/d-id/1109571? Udemy Comes To Corporate Training] ''Information Week''. April 16, 2013</ref>
As of 2018, there are more than 80,000 courses on the website.<ref name="inverse"/>
==History== In 2007, Udemy (you-duh-mee) <ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4q-5bCx78kI/ ABCs of Udemy]. "Udemy". August 25, 2015.</ref> founder Eren Bali built software for a live virtual classroom while living in [[Turkey]]. He saw potential in making the product free for everyone, and moved to [[Silicon Valley]] to found a company two years later. The site was launched by Bali, Oktay Caglar and [[Gagan Biyani]] in early 2010.<ref>[http://www.udemy.com/u/erenbali/ Eren Bali biography]. ''Udemy.com''.</ref>
In February 2010, the founders tried to raise venture capital funding, but the idea failed to impress investors and they were rejected 30 times, according to Gagan Biyani.<ref name=venturehacks/> In response to this, they [[bootstrapping|bootstrapped]] the development of the product and launched Udemy—"The Academy of You"—in May 2010.<ref name=venturehacks>[http://venturehacks.com/articles/udemy How Udemy got oversubscribed]. ''Venture Hacks''. September 10, 2010.</ref>
Within a few months, 1,000 instructors had created about 2,000 courses, and Udemy had nearly 10,000 registered users. Based on this favorable market reaction, they decided to attempt another round of financing, and raised $1 million in venture funding by August.<ref name=xconomy>Roushe, Wade. [http://www.xconomy.com/san-francisco/2010/08/31/udemy-collects-1-million-to-expand-casual-learning-platform/ Udemy Collects $1 Million to Expand Casual Learning Platform]. ''Xconomy''. August 31, 2010.</ref><ref name=techcrunch>Toto, Serkan. [https://techcrunch.com/2010/08/31/udemy-funding/ Udemy Scores $1M In Seed Funding, Aims To Democratize Online Learning]. ''TechCrunch''. August 31, 2010.</ref>
In October 2011, the company raised an additional $3 million in [[Series A funding]] led by [[Groupon]] investors [[Eric Lefkofsky]] and [[Brad Keywell]], as well as [[500 Startups]] and MHS Capital.<ref name=tc>{{cite web|last=Tsotsis|first=Alexia|title=Crowdsourced Learning Platform Udemy Raises $3 Million From Lightbank And Others|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/10/12/crowdsourced-academy-udemy-raises-3-million/|publisher=TechCrunch}}</ref>
In December 2012, the company raised $12 million in [[Venture capital financing#The Second Stage|Series B funding]] led by [[Insight Venture Partners]], as well as Lightbank Capital, MHS Capital and Learn Capital, bringing Udemy's total funding to $16 million.<ref name=twelve>{{cite web|last=Empson|first=Rip|title=Online Learning Marketplace Udemy Lands $12M To Expand Its Course Catalog, Go Cross-Platform|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/12/07/online-learning-marketplace-udemy-lands-12m-to-expand-its-course-catalog-go-cross-platform/|publisher=TechCrunch}}</ref>
On April 22, 2014, the Wall Street Journal's Digital edition reported that Dennis Yang, [[Chief Operating Officer]] of Udemy was named CEO, replacing Eren Bali.<ref name=WSHD4-22-14>Kolodny, Lora. [https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2014/04/22/udemy-appoints-dennis-yang-ceo-eren-bali-steps-aside-to-lead-product/ Udemy Appoints Dennis Yang CEO; Eren Bali Steps Aside to Lead Product] Venture Dispatch, ''Wall Street Journal Digital.'' April 22, 2014</ref>
In May 2014, Udemy raised another $32 million in a Series C funding, led by [[Norwest Venture Partners]], as well as Insight Venture Partners and MHS Capital.<ref name=32million>Sailors, John. [http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/morning_call/2014/05/udemy-raises-32-million-online-learning-norwest.html Udemy raises $32 million for online learning marketplace] ''San Francisco Business Times.'' May 8, 2014</ref>
In June 2015, Udemy raised a $65 million Series D financing round, led by Stripes Group. Now Udemy joined another online learning house Skillsdox Inc of Canada to open up School of Skills in India.
In June 2016, Udemy raised $60 million from [[Naspers|Naspers Ventures]] as a follow-up to the $65 million Series D round of financing from June 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/06/02/udemy-raises-60m-from-naspers-to-grow-its-online-education-platform-globally/|title=Udemy raises $60M from Naspers to grow its online education platform globally|date=2016-06-02|website=VentureBeat|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref>
On June 1, 2017, Udemy announced that the board of the company has appointed Kevin H. Johnson as its new chief executive officer effective immediately.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://about.udemy.com/press-releases/udemy-board-appoints-kevin-h-johnson-as-new-ceo/|title=Udemy Board Appoints Kevin H. Johnson as New CEO {{!}} Udemy About|date=2017-06-01|work=Udemy About|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/udemy-picks-kevin-h-johnson-as-new-ceo-1496430637|title=Udemy Picks Kevin H. Johnson as New CEO|last=|first=|date=2017-06-02|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-02-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660|subscription=y}}</ref>
==Overview== Udemy serves as a platform that allows instructors to build online courses on topics of their choosing. Using Udemy's course development tools they can upload video, [[PowerPoint]] presentations, [[PDF]]s, audio, [[ZIP (file format)|zip files]] and live classes to create courses.<ref name=about>[http://www.udemy.com/static/about.html About Udemy]. ''Udemy.com.''</ref> Instructors can also engage and interact with users via online discussion boards.
Courses are offered across a breadth of categories, including business and [[entrepreneurship]], academics, the arts, health and fitness, language, music, and technology.<ref name=about/> Most classes are in practical subjects such as [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]] software or using an [[iPhone]] camera.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Finder|first1=Alan|title=A Surge in Growth for a New Kind of Online Course|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/26/technology/personaltech/a-surge-in-growth-for-a-new-kind-of-online-course.html|accessdate=25 September 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=September 25, 2013}}</ref> Udemy also offers Udemy for Business, enabling businesses access to a targeted suite of over 2,000 training courses on topics from digital marketing tactics to office productivity, [[design]], [[management]], [[Computer programming|programming]], and more. With Udemy for Business, organizations can also create custom learning portals for corporate training.<ref name=ufo>{{cite web|title=What is UFO?|url=https://www.udemy.com/organizations/|publisher=Udemy}}</ref>
Udemy offers paid and free courses, depending on the instructor.<ref>{{cite web|last=Empson|first=Rip|title=With Over 6,000 Courses Now Live, Udemy Brings Its Learning Marketplace To iOS To Let You Study On The Go|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/04/02/with-over-6000-courses-now-live-udemy-brings-its-learning-marketplace-to-ios-to-let-you-study-on-the-go/|work=TechCrunch|publisher=AOL|accessdate=4 May 2013}}</ref>
Instructor compensation from tuition varies based on who invests in marketing to attract students to Udemy. Instructors earn 97% of all tuition revenues if the instructor's own reputation or marketing attracts the student. Udemy retains 50% of the earnings if the student is attracted by the site's own marketing or other coursework, and the instructor earns just 25% of the tuition if a Udemy promotional affiliate attracts the student to the site and course. In the latter case, the affiliate earns 50% of the tuition, and the remaining 50% is split between Udemy and the instructor.<ref>[https://www.udemy.com/teach/] udemy.com/teach ] ''Udemy Teach Page.'' Retrieved June 18, 2014.</ref> In 2015, the top 10 instructors made more than $17 million in total revenue.<ref name="inverse">{{cite news|last1=Groden|first1=Claire|title=Udemy's Exodus, Amazon's Gain|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/17307-growing-pains-at-online-education-startup-udemy-hit-as-amazon-rumors-swirl|accessdate=25 September 2016|publisher=Inverse|date=June 22, 2016}}</ref>
In April 2013, Udemy offered an [[mobile app|app]] for [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] [[iOS]], allowing students to take classes directly from [[iPhone]]s;<ref name=ios>{{cite web|last=Heussner|first=Ki Mae|title=Exclusive: Udemy lands on mobile so students can learn on the go|url=http://gigaom.com/2013/04/02/udemy-lands-on-mobile-so-students-can-learn-on-the-go/|publisher=Gigaom}}</ref> The Android version was launched in January 2014.<ref name=vb>{{cite web|last=Farr|first=Christina|title=Udemy launches its Android app to bring you online education on the go|url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/01/15/udemy-launches-its-android-app-to-bring-you-online-education-on-the-go/|publisher=VentureBeat}}</ref> As of January 2014, the iOS app had been downloaded over 1 million times, and 20 percent of Udemy users access their courses via mobile.<ref name=g>{{cite web|last=Hockenson|first=Lauren|title=Udemy brings its education marketplace to Android|url=http://gigaom.com/2014/01/15/udemy-brings-its-course-marketplace-to-android/|publisher=Gigaom}}</ref> In July 2016, Udemy expanded their iOS platform to include [[Apple TV]].<ref name=appletv>{{cite web|title=Introducing Udemy for Apple TV|url=https://about.udemy.com/udemy-news/introducing-udemy-for-apple-tv/|publisher=Udemy}}</ref>
===Massive open online course (MOOC)=== Udemy is part of the growing MOOC movement available outside the traditional university system,<ref name=mooc>{{cite web|title=What You Need to Know About MOOCs|url=http://chronicle.com/article/What-You-Need-to-Know-About/133475/|publisher=Chronicle of Higher Education}}</ref><ref name=mo>{{cite web|last=LEWIN|first=TAMAR|title=Instruction for Masses Knocks Down Campus Walls|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/05/education/moocs-large-courses-open-to-all-topple-campus-walls.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> and has been noted for the variety of courses offered.<ref name=ab>{{cite web|last=Littlefield|first=Jamie|title=Top Massively Open Online Courses (MOOCs)|url=http://distancelearn.about.com/od/isitforyou/tp/Top-Massively-Open-Online-Courses-Moocs.htm|publisher=About.com}}</ref>
==Reception== Udemy has been discussed in ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The China Post]]'', ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'', the ''[[BBC]]'' ''[[YPN]]'' and ''[[TechCrunch]]'', with ''[[Mashable]]'' noting "Udemy offers an experience that rivals the real classroom, and should prove to be a useful utility for teachers and students of all subject matters."<ref name=techcrunch/><ref name=nytimes>Lynley, Matthew. [https://www.nytimes.com/external/venturebeat/2010/08/31/31venturebeat-online-teaching-platform-udemy-raises-1m-sti-76566.html Online Teaching Platform Udemy Raises $1M, Still Too Cool for School]. ''The New York Times''. August 31, 2010.</ref><ref name=chinapost>Chapman, Glenn. [http://www.chinapost.com.tw/business/company-focus/2010/09/02/270986/p1/Online-learning.htm Online learning startup rises on US$1 mil. funding from 'angel' investors]. ''The China Post''. September 2, 2010.</ref><ref name=fastcompany>Schomer, Stephanie. [https://onlinecourses.ooo Free Online Courses for All]. ''Online Courses''. December 2, 2010.</ref><ref name=mashable>Van Grove, Jennifer. [http://mashable.com/2010/05/13/udemy/ Get a Real-Life Learning Experience in Udemy’s Virtual Classrooms]. ''Mashable''. May 13, 2010.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/click_online/9720231.stm |title=Ivy League education free on the web |author=Sumi Das |date=15 May 2012 |publisher=BBC Click |accessdate=15 May 2012}}</ref>
In 2014, ''[[Forbes]]'' named Udemy cofounder Eren Bali as part of their "30 Under 30" of "the brightest stars in 15 different fields under the age of 30."<ref name=under>{{cite web|title=30 Under 30|url=https://www.forbes.com/special-report/2014/30-under-30/education.html|publisher=Forbes}}</ref>
Noted businessman [[Jack Welch]] has developed an online MBA program, offered through the [[Jack Welch Management Institute]] (JWMI) at [[Strayer University]], which acquired JWMI assets in November 2011.<ref>Eckert, Barton. [http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/news/2011/11/11/strayer-buys-jack-welch-management.html Strayer Education buys Jack Welch Management Institute] Washington Business Journal, November 11, 2001.</ref> Udemy became the MOOC platform for the institute's Welch Way courseware in November 2012, and promoted this Jack Welch connection.<ref>[http://www.advfn.com/news_The-Jack-Welch-Management-Institute-and-Udemy-Join_55098528.html The Jack Welch Management Institute and Udemy Join Forces to Deliver Online Management Training Courses] AVFN.com.</ref>
==Piracy concerns== In November 2015, Udemy was accused of publishing and profiting from pirated courses.<ref>{{Cite web|title = How Udemy Is Profiting From Piracy|url = https://medium.com/@robconery/how-udemy-is-profiting-from-piracy-5638b929ffca|website = Medium|accessdate = 2015-11-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Anger at ‘stolen’ online courses on Udemy|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-34952382|work=BBC News|accessdate=2015-12-05|date=2015-11-30|author=Dave Lee}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/11/29/9813780/udemy-pirated-course-copyright-troy-hunt|title=Udemy faces criticism for profiting from pirated online courses|work=The Verge|date=2015-11-29|author=Amar Toor|accessdate=2015-12-05}}</ref> The CEO, Dennis Yang, answered the accusations in a blog post, looking specifically at one accusation and stating that Udemy did not profit from that instance of piracy.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Maintaining the integrity of our Udemy community|url = https://blog.udemy.com/maintaining-the-integrity-of-our-udemy-community/}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{MOOC}}
{{commons category}}
[[Category:Community websites]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2010]] [[Category:Educational technology companies]] [[Category:Virtual learning environments]] [[Category:Learning management systems]] [[Category:Online education]] [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]] [[Category:2010 establishments in California]] [[Category:500 Startups companies]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name = Walden Bello | image = Walden.jpg | imagesize = | smallimage = | caption = | order = | office = Member of the Philippine House of Representatives for [[Akbayan]] Partylist | alongside = | term_start = June 30, 2007 | term_end = March 16, 2015 | office2 = Professor of Sociology and Public Administration at [[University of the Philippines]] | term_start2 = | term_end2 = 2007 | birth_name = Walden Flores Bello | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|11|11}} | birth_place = [[Manila]], [[Philippines]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] | party = [[Communist Party of the Philippines]] (1970s-2000s)
[[Akbayan Citizens' Action Party]] (2000s-present) | spouse = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[Ateneo de Manila University]], [[Princeton University]] | occupation = | profession = | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Walden Flores Bello''' (born November 11, 1945) is a Filipino [[academic]], [[environmentalist]], and [[social worker]] who served as a member of the [[House of Representatives of the Philippines]]. He is a professor of sociology and [[public administration]] at the [[University of the Philippines Diliman]], as well as executive director of [[Focus on the Global South]]. ==Early life== Bello was born in [[Manila]], [[Philippines]]. His family paid for his [[Jesuit]] schooling at [[Ateneo de Manila University]] and he attended [[grad school]] at [[Princeton University]]. While attending Princeton in the United States, he was introduced to the [[anti-war movement]] and led an occupation of the [[Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs|Woodrow Wilson Center]]. The confrontation with police during these protests radicalized Bello and inspired him to pursue a life of activism. For his graduate studies, he traveled to Chile and stayed in shanty towns following [[Salvador Allende]]'s [[socialist]] rise to the presidency.{{cite news|last1=Ramos Shahani|first1=Lila|title=The Kentex Fire: A Conversation with Walden Bello|url=http://www.philstar.com/opinion/2015/05/26/1458669/kentex-fire-conversation-walden-bello|accessdate=27 January 2016|work=philstar.com|agency=''[[The Philippine Star]]''|date=26 May 2015}} When he returned to the United States to defend his dissertation, he lost his ability to return to the Philippines after his passport had been revoked when the declaration of [[Martial Law]] by then-President [[Ferdinand Marcos]] on September 21, 1972.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Professor, 2 others nabbed (2:29 p.m.) |url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/static/net/2006/02/24/professor.2.others.nabbed.(2.29.p.m.).html |work= |publisher=Sun.Star |date=February 24, 2006|accessdate=2007-06-27 }} ==Activism== After earning his PhD in sociology in 1975 from Princeton, he then became part of the anti-Marcos movement, began teaching at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] and became a member of the [[Communist Party of the Philippines]]. In 1978 after being arrested multiple times during protests, he was arrested after leading the takeover of the Philippine consulate in San Francisco. Bello was later released following a [[hunger strike]] to bring attention to the situation the Philippines was facing.{{cite web|title=About Walden|url=http://www.waldenbello.org/about-walden/|website=Walden Bello|accessdate=27 January 2016|language=en-US}} In the early-1980s, Bello also broke into the [[World Bank]] headquarters and stole 3,000 pages of confidential documents that he said would show the connection of the IMF and World Bank to Marcos. He later wrote ''Development Debacle: the World Bank in the Philippines'' in 1982 surrounding the documents stating that this publication contributed toward the 1986 [[People Power Revolution]] in the Philippines, with Bello returning to his native state two years later. In 1995, Bello co-founded [[Focus on the Global South]], a policy research institute based in [[Bangkok]], Thailand. Bello had also led teach-ins during the [[1999 Seattle WTO protests]] and protested internationally against globalization at the [[2001 G8 summit]], the [[World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference of 2003|WTO Ministerial Conference of 2003]], the [[World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference of 2005|WTO Ministerial Conference of 2005]] and was banned from the 2006 World Bank-IMF Conference in Singapore. Politically, Bello began to turn away from the Communist Party of the Philippines after he heard that they allegedly killed individuals in the 1980s and 1990s that were accused of being [[double agent]]s. Bello later joined the [[Akbayan Citizens' Action Party]] and became a member of congress in 2010. In March 2015, Bello resigned his position in congress due to conflicts with President [[Benigno Aquino III]] that surrounded the Disbursement Acceleration Program and the [[Mamasapano incident]]. He ran for senator in 2016 but lost.{{cite news|last1=Aceron|first1=Joy|last2=Isaac|first2=Francis|title=That thing called resignation|url=http://www.rappler.com/views/imho/86797-walden-bello-resignation|accessdate=27 January 2016|work=[[Rappler]]|date=14 March 2015}} He currently sits on the board of directors of the [[International Forum on Globalization]]{{cite web |url=http://www.ifg.org/about/bod.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302041256/http://ifg.org/about/bod.htm |archivedate=March 2, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} and on the board of directors of the leftist think-tank [[Center for Economic and Policy Research]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cepr.net/index.php/board/ |title=Board of Directors |date=March 2015 |publisher=Center for Economic and Policy Research |accessdate=13 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150318070636/http://www.cepr.net/index.php/board/ |archivedate=March 18, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} He is also a member of the regional [[Greenpeace]]. ==Political positions== ''[[Socialist Worker]]'' described Bello as "one of the most articulate and prolific voices on the international left" and that "he has devoted most of his life to fighting [[imperialism]] and corporate globalization".{{cite web|title=Why Walden Bello needs your support|url=http://socialistworker.org/2005-1/532/532_07_WaldenBello.shtml|website=socialistworker.org|publisher=''[[Socialist Worker]]''|accessdate=27 January 2016}} Bello was also a supporter of [[Hugo Chávez]] and was impressed by his opposition to the United States, stating after Chávez's death that he was "a class act, one impossible to follow. Wherever you are right now, give ’em hell".{{cite news|last1=Bello|first1=Walden|title=I’ll miss Hugo|url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/48265/ill-miss-hugo|accessdate=27 January 2016|agency=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''|date=7 March 2013}} == Books == Bello has authored and edited a number of non-fiction books. Among them are the following:{{Cite web|url=http://www.waldenbello.org/category/s5-publications/c13-books/|title=Books|last=|first=|date=|website=Walden Bello|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-30}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Walden-Bello/e/B00CQ8D9MU|title=Walden Bello: Books, Biography, Blog, Audiobooks, Kindle|last=|first=|date=|website=Amazon|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-30}} * ''Capitalism’s Last Stand?: Deglobalization in the Age of Austerity'' (2013) * ''The Food Wars'' (2009) * ''The Anti-Development State: The Political Economy of Permanent Crisis in the Philippines'' (2006), with co-authors Herbert Docena, Marissa de Guzman, and Mary Lou Malig * ''Deglobalization: Ideas for a New World Economy: Global Issues'' (2005) * ''Dilemmas of Domination: The Unmaking of the American Empire'' (2005) * ''Global Finance: New Thinking on Regulating Speculative Capital Markets'' (2000), editor, with co-editor Nicola Bullard * ''A Siamese Tragedy: Development and Disintegration in Modern Thailand'' (1999), with co-author Shea Cunningham ==Recognition== In 2003, Bello was awarded the [[Right Livelihood Award]], whose website describes him as "one of the leading critics of the current model of [[economic globalization]], combining the roles of intellectual and activist."[http://www.rightlivelihood.org/recip/2003/bello.htm] Bello is also a fellow of the [[Transnational Institute]] (based in [[Amsterdam]]), and is a columnist for ''[[Foreign Policy in Focus]]''. In March 2008 he was named Outstanding Public Scholar for 2008 by the [[International Studies Association]].[http://www.waldenbello.org/] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.waldenbello.org/ Walden Bello's website] *Biographical information on [https://web.archive.org/web/20081117083425/http://www.rightlivelihood.org/bello.html Right Livelihood Award website] *[http://www.tni.org/users/walden-bello Biographical information] from the [[Transnational Institute]] *[http://www.focusweb.org Focus on the Global South] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bello, Walden}} [[Category:Anti-globalization activists]] [[Category:Anti-globalization writers]] [[Category:Anti-imperialism]] [[Category:Development specialists]] [[Category:Filipino activists]] [[Category:Filipino communists]] [[Category:Filipino sociologists]] [[Category:Filipino writers]] [[Category:Foreign policy writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the House of Representatives of the Philippines for Akbayan]] [[Category:People associated with Greenpeace]] [[Category:People from Quezon City]] [[Category:Politicians from Metro Manila]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Right Livelihood Award laureates]] [[Category:Sociology educators]] [[Category:Ateneo de Manila University alumni]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley faculty]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Center for Economic and Policy Research]]
